input:
2. A 14-year-old boy arrives at the clinic complaining of sudden, excruciating pain in his right testicle that started about 2 hours ago while he was sleeping. He also notes swelling and redness of the scrotum, accompanied by feeling nauseous but no fever or urinary symptoms. He denies any recent trauma or heavy physical activity. On physical exam, the right testicle is tender, firm, and noticeably higher than the left, with an absent cremasteric reflex on that side. His left testicle is of normal size and non-tender. Urinalysis is normal, showing no signs of infection. A prompt scrotal color Doppler ultrasound reveals absent blood flow to the right testicle, consistent with acute testicular torsion. Given the time-sensitive nature, he is immediately prepped for surgical detorsion to salvage testicular function.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: I need to explain that I suddenly started feeling really bad and that my testicle hurts a lot, so I should tell the doctor that right away. I also want to mention the swelling and how it all just came on suddenly, to make it clear I didn’t do anything to cause it. I should sound worried but maybe not totally clear about everything since I don’t really understand what’s happening. 

ANSWER: I… I don’t know, it just started hurting really bad in my right testicle, like out of nowhere. It’s all swollen and red and I feel kinda sick, like I wanna throw up. I’ve never felt anything like this before, and I was just sleeping when it started.

output: Um, it kind of hit really fast, like out of nowhere, and it’s been just super sharp and bad since then. I didn’t feel anything before, and now it’s like really painful and weird, and my testicle just feels way different than usual.
